III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section Health services; policies and procedures.
Description (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 6/12/2025, Youth A did not receive medical treatment for
slamming his body and head against a window door. Youth A had
a black eye and bruises on his wrist and neck.
Investigation Complainant was called on 6/17/2025 and 7/2/2025. Messages
were left and a phone call has not been returned.
Assistant Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility
on 6/17/2025. He stated he was aware of the incident that
occurred on 6/12/2025 with Youth A and several staff, however,
he was not present for the incident. He explained, prior to a youth
receiving medical treatment, a supervisor will have a conversation
with that youth to inquire if they want or need to seek medical
treatment and if they need anything additional. He also reported
Chief Administrator did a follow-up interview with Youth A on
6/16/2025 regarding the incident from 6/12/2025. Assistant
Director was not present for that interview.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 6/17/2025. CA stated he was aware of the incident that
occurred on 6/12/2205 with Youth A, however, he was not present
for the incident. CA stated he did a visual and verbal assessment
of Youth A on 6/16/2025, and he did not observe any injuries.
Youth A did not have a black eye, or bruises on his wrist and no
blood on his forehead. CA stated Youth A did not complain of any
pain or injuries when CA observed him. It did not appear to CA
that Youth A had any lingering pain or injuries. Youth A did not
request medical treatment. CA concluded after the assessment
that Youth A did not need to seek medical treatment.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
6/17/2025. Youth A stated that on an unknown date, he was
playing around with his medicine pill and was pretending to take
his hand away. Staff 3 disciplined him and stated he had to write
100 sentences. Youth A stated he was never going to write the
sentences because he did not feel he deserved to be disciplined.
He stated this is why he told Supervisor 1 he was refusing to do
2

his sentences on 6/12/2025. Youth A stated he doesn’t remember
much from the incident on 6/12/2025. He recalled initially being
restrained by unknown staff and being handcuffed. He does recall
not being able to move his muscles. He stated once he was in
Max II, the seclusion room, he recalls trying to close the door and
all the staff were trying to stop him. Youth A does recall banging
his head on the wall and the door window. He did not recall how
many times he banged his head. He stated due to the handcuffs
being too tight, his wrists were hurting. He stated he did tell Staff 3
that his leg was hurting and thought it was broken. He reported he
kept asking Staff 3 if he was going to take him to the hospital. He
stated Staff 3 ignored him and left him in the room. He reported
this was the first time he had been restrained.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/2/2025. Supervisor 1 stated she started her shift at 3:00pm on
6/12/2025. She recalled at 4:00pm, Youth A had sentences to turn
in due to receiving discipline from a previous incident that was
assigned by Staff 3. She asked Youth A if he completed his
sentences and he told her he was not done and he was not going
to his room. She tried to speak with him about completing his
sentences and Youth A said he was not giving her the sentences,
and they were somewhere in the toilet. She offered to give him
another piece of discipline paper and use a pencil, but he refused.
Due to his refusal, she called for the floor to be cleared and the
other youth to go back to their rooms. Once all youth were off the
floor, Supervisor 2 and herself continued to talk to him, but Youth
A didn’t respond. Supervisor 1 then requested for Supervisor 2 to
talk to Youth A alone, however, Youth A was still not responding
and would not comply with any directives. Supervisor 1 then gave
directions to Staff 4 and Staff 5 to escort him to Max II. Supervisor
1 gave Youth A the option to walk to the Max room on his own, but
he did not get up out of his seat. She stated Staff 4 and Staff 5
each stood on the side of Youth A, put their arms under his arms
and lifted him out of his seat. Youth A fell to the ground and would
not get back up. Youth A began kicking staff and rolling around on
the floor. She then instructed Staff 4 and Staff 5 to put handcuffs
on Youth A. Once the handcuffs were on, Staff 4 and Staff 5
picked up Youth A from the ground and escorted him to the
seclusion room. Supervisor 1, Staff 4 and Staff 5 attempted to
take the handcuffs off Youth A but Youth A kept moving his arms
around and wouldn’t let them take the handcuffs off. When staff
tried to exit the room, Youth A was grabbing on their legs and
arms. Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 4 and Staff 5, and Supervisor 1 had to
leave the room one-by-one, as Youth A would not let them go.
Youth A attempted to put his body between the door so that staff
3

would be unable to close it. Eventually, all staff were able to leave
the room and leave Youth A in the room. Supervisor 1 instructed
Staff 1 to monitor Youth A through the door window. She stated
Youth A was hitting his head on the door window. He was also
jumping, yelling, screaming, drooling, and foaming at the mouth.
She stated Youth A was not listening to staff orders, and he was
not verbally responding, but making moaning noises. He
eventually wore himself out and laid down in front of the door and
appeared to be asleep. She gave directions for Staff 1, Staff 4 and
Staff 5 to enter the room to remove the handcuffs. Once staff
entered the room, Youth A became upset again. He began to
resist and wouldn’t allow them to take off his handcuffs. She
radioed Supervisor 2 and Staff 3 to put the other youth down in
their room on the treatment unit and requested additional help.
Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, Staff 5, Supervisor 1 and
Supervisor 2 assisted with getting Youth A on the ground and
getting his handcuffs off. She stated Youth A kept grabbing staff
ankles and legs, and this caused everyone to fall over one
another. Eventually all staff were able to leave the room.
Supervisor 1 recalled it was very difficult to get Youth A to comply
with any directive and he was verbally not responding the entire
time. She did not observe any bruises or swelling on Youth A’s
body. Youth A did not complain about being in pain. Supervisor 1
stated she had to leave the building and go to the Emergency
Room (ER) due to Youth A falling on her leg when trying to get the
handcuffs off him. Supervisor 1 did not feel it was necessary for
Youth A to seek medical treatment.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/2/2025.
Staff 1 stated on 6/12/2025, she was in the dayroom with the
youth on the detention unit and they all were playing games and
doing different activities while on their break. Staff 1 stated
sometime before 6:00pm, Youth A was asked to go to his room by
Supervisor 1 because he didn’t finish his sentences. Youth A
refused and Supervisor 1 told Staff 4 to remove the other youth
from the unit. Youth A was sitting in the chair and did not respond
verbally. Staff 4 and Staff 5 took Youth A under each arm and
while attempting to lift him up, Youth A fell to the floor. She began
holding Youth’s A legs because he started kicking at staff and she
was trying to keep him still. She recalls someone mentioning
putting handcuffs on Youth A but doesn’t recall who gave the
order. Once the handcuffs were on, Staff 4 and Staff 5 escorted
Youth A to Max II while Supervisor 1, Supervisor 2, Staff 2 and
herself followed behind. She stated once Youth A was in the room
it became tug of war with him. Youth A was throwing himself and
his body around on the floor while they were trying to get the
4

handcuffs off him. Once the handcuffs were off, and all staff were
able to leave the room, she monitored Youth A through the door
window. She stated Youth A was taking his handcuffs and
banging them up against the glass door window, scraping his
handcuffs on the wall, and banging his head all over the room.
Through the window, she kept telling Youth A that it would be
okay and letting him know that it was okay to cry. Staff 1 felt as if
he was dealing with something emotionally. Youth A did state to
her that he did not want to talk. Youth A tired himself out, sat
down, and started to fall asleep on the floor. She told Supervisor 1
he was asleep. Supervisor 1, Supervisor 2, Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4
and Staff 5 all entered the room. Youth A woke up and he became
uncooperative again. Youth A was grabbing on all staff legs as
they were trying to exit the room. Youth A was not hurting staff,
but he would not let them go and was very clingy. He began to cry
and that is when Supervisor 2 and Staff 3 were able to exit the
room. Staff 1 did not observe Youth A with a black eye and there
was no bleeding or bruising on his wrists from the handcuffs. She
did observe him limping when he came out of the room to take a
shower. Staff 3 and Staff 6 were escorting him, and she overheard
Staff 6 state Youth A’s leg looked swollen. When Staff 1 saw
Youth A the next day, he was walking completely fine.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/2/2025.
Staff 2 stated he was on the treatment unit when he received a
call on the radio to come to detention and it was an emergency.
When he entered the detention unit, Youth A was sitting in a chair,
however, he was not aware of what happened to receive
assistance on the detention unit. Youth A was refusing to speak,
answer or go to his room. Supervisor 1 instructed all staff to go to
the control room so that she could talk to Youth A alone. Staff
were in the control room for about 15-20 minutes, and they were
called out of the room and Youth A was not complying with orders.
Staff 4 and Staff 5 put their arm under each of Youth’s A arms,
and when they stood Youth A up, Youth A started to kick and staff,
and Youth A fell to the ground. While on the ground, staff kept
telling Youth A to calm down, however, Youth A was fighting and
kicking staff. He recalls someone saying to put handcuffs on
Youth A, but he does not recall who. Youth A was escorted to Max
II and he was fighting staff the entire time. When staff tried to take
the handcuffs off Youth A, Youth A would not let them do it.
Supervisor 1 stated to leave the handcuffs on, and staff exited the
room. Once staff were out of the room, Youth A maneuvered his
handcuffs to be in front of him and was banging on the door. At
some point, Youth A laid down and Supervisor 1 instructed to take
the handcuffs of him. Youth A would not let them take the
5

handcuffs of him and he was grabbing on staff legs and arms.
Youth A would also not let staff leave out the room and he would
get in between the door to prevent it from closing. This occurred
for 20-30 minutes. Youth A eventually started to break down and
cry, and he let all staff leave the room. Youth A laid down and was
quiet. Youth A never expressed that he was in any type of pain.
He did not have a black eye, any bruising or bleeding from his
wrist and no bleeding from his head/forehead area. When he saw
Youth A later on walking to the shower, Youth A was not limping.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/2/2025.
Staff 3 stated on an unknown date, she was passing medication to
the youth and Youth A kept snatching his hand back and forth
when receiving his medication and proceeded to do this after she
told him to stop. She then assigned him 100 sentences as
discipline. On 6/12/2025, in the dayroom, Youth A was asked by
Supervisor 1 if he completed his sentences, after Youth A stated
that he didn’t, Supervisor 1 told him to go to his room to finish the
sentences and Youth A refused. Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 4, Staff 5,
Supervisor 1, Supervisor 2 and herself all tried to process with
Youth A for over twenty minutes. Staff kept asking him to go to his
room to complete his sentences. Staff went into the control room
while Supervisor 2 sat in the dayroom and talked to Youth A for a
one-on-one conversation. Supervisor 1 checked to see if any
progress was made and Youth A still refused to comply. All staff
came out of the control room and were instructed to escort Youth
A to Max II. Staff 4 and Staff 5 were interlocked with Youth A,
however, Youth A would not walk. Youth A started swinging his
arms, and Staff 4, Staff 5 and Youth A all fell to the ground. Youth
A was on the floor and throwing his body around. Staff 3 grabbed
his left leg and Staff 1 grabbed his right leg so that he would stop
kicking staff. Staff 1 and herself had one hand on the back of
Youth’s A ankle and one hand on the back of his kneecap. They
applied pressure to his superficial peroneal. She recalls staff
putting handcuffs on Youth A but she did not recall which staff.
After about 15 minutes, Youth A calmed down and when staff
picked him back up, he began kicking again. Once Staff 3 and
Staff 4 took Youth A to Max II, Youth A kept grabbing on staff legs
and would not let them leave out of the room. Once staff were
able to leave the room, Youth A was able to get his handcuffs in
front of him and was hitting his handcuffs on the door window
while also running and charging at the door and banging his head.
Youth A started to bite at his handcuffs. Staff 1 took over watching
him as Youth A was upset that Staff 3 assigned him the
sentences. Staff 3 went back to the treatment unit while Staff 1
continued to monitor Youth A. Supervisor 1 called for Staff 3 to
6

come back, as Youth A was calm and she wanted to get his
handcuffs off. Youth A began resisting when one handcuff was off
and Supervisor 1 radioed for youth to be put in their rooms and
needed additional assistance. Youth A wouldn’t allow staff to close
the door once his handcuffs were off, and he kept grabbing on
staff. Youth A put his body in between the door and staff were not
able to close the door. Staff 3 stated this went on for twenty
minutes. In the end, Youth A grabbed her leg, and she began to
speak to him calmly. She spoke to him for fifteen minutes and
Youth A told her that he hates it there and he wants to go home to
see his sister. Once she left the room, she spoke to Youth A
through the door window. Youth A reported to her his leg was sore
and asked him if he would like ice or Tylenol. Youth A told her
“no”. Staff 6 and herself assisted with taking Youth A to the
shower and he was refusing to put pressure on his leg, and he
was hopping. Youth A was holding onto her and Staff 5 while
walking to the bathroom for a shower. They put a chair in the
shower so Youth A could sit down while taking a shower. When
Youth A came out of the shower, he brought a chair out with him.
He was still hopping and refusing to put pressure on his leg.
Supervisor 2 stated Youth A did not appear to be in excruciating
pain. They escorted Youth A back into the Max room for the night.
Staff 6 and herself called CA to inquire if Youth A needs to go
seek treatment that night or the morning, and CA told them he will
check on him and his leg.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/2/2025.
Staff 4 stated on 6/12/2025, all the youth were in the dayroom for
free time. Youth A was sitting in a chair when Supervisor 1 went to
Staff 4 to inquire if Youth A finished his sentences. Staff 5 stated
no, and Supervisor 1 informed him Youth A is not allowed to be on
the floor until he completes his sentences. Supervisor 1 and Staff
5 told Youth A he needed to go to his room. Youth A kept telling
them no and stated the reason was stupid for why he received
discipline. Supervisor 1 requested to clear the dayroom of the
other youth. As staff were talking to Youth A, Youth A was quiet
and refused to get up. Supervisor 1 requested Staff 4 and Staff 5
escort Youth A to Max II. Youth A was sitting in a chair and Staff 4
and Staff 5 put their arm under his arm to get him up, and when
they pulled him up, Youth A fell to the ground. Supervisor 1
requested Staff 4 put handcuffs on Youth A. Staff 4 and Staff 5
escorted Youth A to Max II. After thirty minutes Supervisor 1
requested Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 5 and himself remove the
handcuffs from Youth A. Once in the room, they were able to
remove the handcuffs, however, Youth A started grabbing staff
legs and he was not letting anyone leave the room. Youth A was
7

also maneuvering his body in between the door so that staff could
not close it. Staff 4 stated this went on for about thirty minutes. He
stated Youth A eventually calmed down and all staff were able to
leave the room. Youth A did not have a black eye, any bruises
above his eyebrow and no bleeding from his forehead. Staff 4 did
observe that Youth A’s wrists were red from the handcuffs but
there was no bleeding. Youth A never expressed to anyone that
he was in pain and he did not observe him limping.
Staff 5 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/2/2025.
Staff 5 stated on 6/12/2025, Supervisor 1 told Youth A to go to his
room to do his sentences. He recalls Youth A saying the
sentences are “bullshit”. Staff 4 and himself were instructed to
escort Youth A to Max 2. He stated that Staff 3 and himself each
had their hand on Youth’s A should and their other hand on his
wrist. When they lifted him up, Youth A fell to the ground. He
stated that once they were able to gain control, Staff 4 and himself
escorted Youth A to Max II. While in Max II, Youth kept latching
onto people and no one was able to leave the room. Staff 5 did
not observe Youth A with a black eye, no bruise above his
eyebrow, however, he did see that Youth A did have a couple
newly scratches around his neck that believed occurred during the
multiple times Youth A was being uncooperative. He heard Youth
A tell Staff 3 that his leg was hurting and Staff 3 discussed with
Youth A that if needed, Youth A will seek treatment.
Staff 6 was interviewed over the phone on 7/2/2025. Staff 6
stated her shift started after the restraint occurred. She was aware
that Youth A needed to shower, so she helped him walk to the
shower from Max II. She stated Youth A couldn’t put pressure on
his leg and it looked slightly swollen. She stated Staff 3 also
assisted in the transport. She called CA to inquire if Youth A
should be treated. CA stated Youth A did not need to be
transported because it was not medically necessary. Staff 6 stated
Youth A was not bleeding anywhere or had any broken bones.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed over the phone on 7/14/2025.
Supervisor 2 stated on 6/12/2025, she was radioed to come to the
dayroom. Once entering, she saw Youth A sitting in a chair and
refusing to go to his room to do his sentences. She stated all staff
left the room so that she could speak to him alone. She stated
Youth A sat quietly for 5-7 minutes with his arms crossed and he
did not say anything to her. Supervisor 1 also spoke to Youth A
and gave him the opportunity to walk to Max II on his own,
however, he refused. Staff 4 and Staff 5 were preparing to escort
Youth A to Max II when Youth A became resistant and there was
8

a command given for everyone to go on the floor. Staff 1 and Staff
3 held Youth A’s legs and ankles to prevent him from kicking staff
so Staff 4 could put handcuffs on him. Staff 4 was instructed to do
this by Supervisor 1. Supervisor 2 left to unlock Max II while Staff
4 and Staff 5 escorted Youth A to the room. Once staff and Youth
A entered the room, Youth A was told to go to the floor for
handcuffs to be taken off, however, he refused. Once staff were
able to get out of the room, Youth A maneuvered his handcuffs in
front of his chest. Supervisor 2 stated Supervisor 1 instructed her
to go back to the treatment unit. Some time went by, and it was
radioed to clear the treatment unit floor and assistance was
needed. Once she arrived to Max II, Youth A had his arms
wrapped around staff legs and commands were giving for Youth A
to let go, however, he would not. Supervisor 2 knelt to Youth A to
get him to back away from the door. Youth A was on the ground,
and he was not allowing staff to leave the room. She heard
Supervisor 1 make a noise and realized Supervisor 1 had
sustained an injury to her leg and she instructed Supervisor 1 to
leave the room. Staff 5 stepped in to assist with trying to get Youth
A’s arm from around staff legs. Supervisor 2 stated Youth A
grabbed her and held her hand. Youth A kept saying he wanted to
go home. Once Youth A let go of her hand, all staff were able to
leave the room. She assisted Supervisor 1 with her injury.
Supervisor 2 stated she did not see any bruising, or a black eye,
or any blood on Youth’s A forehead and no blood or bruising on
his wrists. She did overhear Youth A crying but he never once
complained of pain or an injury. Supervisor 2 did not observe
Youth A limping or any injuries to his leg.

• Physical Restraint of Residents Policy: Mechanical
o Every effort should be made to de-escalate the
situation to avoid the use of physical restraints. If it is
necessary to use them, the staff should take the
necessary precautions to assure the minor’s safety
while preserving building security.
o Procedure: 1. Use of mechanical restraint requires the
approval and presence of the Shift Supervisor/YC
Coordinator. 2. If handcuffs or leg irons are used, when
tactically able, cuffs and irons are to be check for
tightness and double locked. 3. Within 20 minutes of
application, the Shift Supervisor/YC Coordinator will
seek the approval of the Director or his/her designee to
continue the use of the mechanical restraints. 4. The
Shift Supervisor/YC Coordinator is required to be
present until he/she is sure that the restraints have been
applied properly. A staff member must be present
continuously while restraints are being used thereafter.
5. A written record (Incident Report, Unit Report and
Observation Note) shall be kept.
• Isolation of a Resident Policy:
o Procedure: 1. Staff should never open the door to an
isolated resident’s room alone. 2. A resident placed in
isolation should be kept completely separated from the
group. No communication should take place with the
other residents and mail privileges are restructured
during the isolation. No items threatening safety or
security of the residents or the facility should be
permitted in the room. 3. If possible, a resident placed in
isolation should be counseled immediately. The Youth
Specialist who suggested isolation should be the one to
do the counseling. Another staff may be necessary to
avoid further confrontation. The resident must be
counseled at least once during each eight-hour shift.
The counseling should include an evaluation of physical
11

and emotional condition of the resident. An observation
note should be recorded following the
counseling/assessment. 4. Residents in isolation should
be showered once a day. Those in extended isolation
also should be allowed free time out on the unit for 20 to
30 minutes when other residents are not out on the
floor. This should occur on first and second shift. 5.
Residents in isolation should be let out of his/her room
to use the bathroom as needed. Ideally, the residents
will be in a room with a toilet. 6. Residents in isolation
for behavioral reasons will be fed on trays in his/her
room with plastic utensils (no knife). The residents’ first
three meals (excluding breakfast) will be discipline
trays. Regular meals on a tray will be served thereafter.
7. Residents in isolation should be supervised by two
staff during shower time, and anytime they are out of
their room. 8. Residents in isolation will forfeit visitation,
mail and activity privileges. Special privileges may only
be granted by the Director. 9. Residents in isolation
must be visually observed every 15 minutes and the
Check recorded on the isolation checklist during the
entire isolation period.
o Length of Isolation Period: The period of isolation should be
the minimal amount of time required to change the
dangerous atmosphere has caused.
o Authorizations: Any Youth Specialist may isolate a resident
if the situation warrants it. The isolation must be reported
immediately to the Shift Supervisor/YS Coordinator. If the
isolation is longer than 15 minutes, the Shift Supervisor/YS
Coordinator must give approval. YS Coordinators can
